com.ojcoleman.europa.core

Class Evolver<G extends Genotype<?>>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.ojcoleman.europa.configurable.Observable
      • com.ojcoleman.europa.configurable.ConfigurableBase
        • com.ojcoleman.europa.configurable.ComponentBase
          • com.ojcoleman.europa.core.Evolver<G>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Stringable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    DefaultEvolver

    public abstract class Evolver<G extends Genotype<?>>
extends ComponentBase
    Base class for classes that generate the (@link Individual)s for an initial Population and then produce new Individuals based on recombination and mutation of existing members of the population (once they've been evaluated and ranked).
    Author:
    O. J. Coleman

      • mutators

        @Component(description="Component(s) used to mutate genotypes.",
           defaultClass=DummyMutator.class)
protected Mutator<G extends Genotype<?>>[] mutators
        The set of mutators used to mutate genotypes.

      • recombiners

        @Component(description="Component(s) used to recombine genotypes to produce child genotypes.",
           optional=true)
protected Recombiner<G extends Genotype<?>>[] recombiners
        The set of recombiners, if applicable, used to generate children genotypes. This is optional as some algorithms, for example, swarm or colony based do not use recombination.

      • relativeCloneProportion

        @Parameter(description="The relative proportion of children to produce by cloning (relative to the proportions set for recombiners, if any).",
           defaultValue="1")
protected double relativeCloneProportion
        The relative proportion of children to produce by cloning (relative to the proportions set for recombiners, if any)

    • Method Detail

      • evolve

        public abstract void evolve(Population<G,?> population)
        Add Individuals to the given Population based on the current members and optionally species groupings.

        For non-swarm/colony based algorithms, implementations should do things like (taking Species into account if applicable):

        • Select some parents.
        • Generate new Genotypes from parents via the recombiners and/or cloning and then mutate them via the mutators or by calling mutateGenotype(Genotype, boolean) .
        • Select some elites (most likely subset of parents).
        • Remove individuals other than elites from population with Population.removeIndividual(Individual).
        • Add the new Genotypes to the population (Population.addGenotype(Object...)).

        For swarm/colony based algorithms, implementations should do things like:

        • For each member of the population:
        • Generate an updated version of the genotype of the member via the mutators.
        • Remove the member with Population.removeIndividual(Individual) and replace it with the updated genotype via Population.addGenotype(Object...)

      • selectRandomRecombiner

        public Recombiner<G> selectRandomRecombiner()
        Selects a Recombiner from recombiners at random (or the clone operation), taking into account Recombiner.relativeProportion and relativeCloneProportion.
        Returns:
        A Recombiner or null to represent the clone operation.

      • mutateGenotype

        public void mutateGenotype(G genotype,
                  boolean applyAllMutators)
        Mutate the given genotype. This default implementation calls Mutator.mutate(Genotype) for each of the mutators on the given genotype.
        Parameters:
        genotype - The Genotype to mutate.
        applyAllMutators - If set then all mutators will be applied to the given Genotype. If not set then mutators will be applied only if their implementation of Mutator.shouldMutate(Genotype) returns true for the given Genotype.
